Death Valley is located in the northern part of the Mojave Desert in the state of California, USA. It is situated on the border between California and Nevada. The valley is known as one of the hottest and driest places in the world, with temperatures reaching up to 134°F (57°C). It is also the lowest point in North America, at 282 feet (86 m) below sea level.

Death Valley is part of the North American continent, the world's third-largest continent. The continent is home to Canada, the United States, Mexico, Central America, and the Caribbean islands. It is bordered by the Arctic Ocean to the north, the Atlantic Ocean to the east, the Pacific Ocean to the west, and the Caribbean Sea and South America to the south.

Death Valley is a unique and harsh environment, with an extreme climate and topography. It is one of the most iconic natural landmarks of the North American continent, and its vast expanses of desert and other striking geological features make it an incredibly important ecosystem. Its unique geography is an important part of the continent's geological history.
